resources.string: Earth is first and foremost the blue planet.
blue planet
Water covers 70% of our world\'s surface and, of this total water surface, freshwater accounts for only 2.5%, making it one of the planet\'s most precious resources.
Water covers 70% of our world\'s surface

The aquatic environment is a key component of global ecosystems and an essential source of food, biodiversity and economic resources. It is estimated to be the habitat of more than 70% of all life forms. It generates half of the oxygen we consume and absorbs a quarter of all CO2 emissions. Its degradation directly impacts human, animal and environmental health, and influences the spread of diseases and pollutants.
Its degradation directly impacts human, animal and environmental health

In this context, the One Health approach recognizes the interdependence between these three levels of health. Applying it to the aquatic environment allows for the design of integrated strategies for risk surveillance, prevention, and management. This promotes sustainable management that protects both public health and the health of the planet.
One Health approach
sustainable management

With the aim of researching and developing solutions to the problems of sustainability of the aquatic environment, its relationship and interaction with living beings and its influence on human health, iARCUS was created. One of the research institutes that form part of the University of Santiago de Compostela.
researching and developing solutions to the problems of sustainability of the aquatic environment

iARCUS is the Institute for Aquatic Environmental Research for Global Health. Originally founded in 1997 as the Institute of Aquaculture, it changed its name in 2024 after integrating researchers from the former Institute for Research in Chemical and Biological Analysis (IAQBUS) and others not attached to any centre and expanding its scientific agenda, objectives and lines of research. Its headquarters are located in the Campus Vida of the Galician capital, although it has researchers in other campuses of the USC.
Institute for Aquatic Environmental Research for Global Health
the Campus Vida of the Galician capital

Since its creation, the institute has focused on sustainability, dedicating itself to improving aquaculture production of fish, molluscs and crustaceans, researching pollution of the aquatic environment and its impact on human health, and improving technology and knowledge transfer to society, focusing on training for adaptation to climate change and on the importance of respect for the natural environment.
aquaculture production of fish
researching pollution of the aquatic environment and its impact on human health
Its current strategy is part of the ‘One Health’ action framework. This line of action promotes actions that work together to care for environmental, animal and human health.
‘One Health’ action

iARCUS has set itself five key objectives to become a scientific benchmark committed to society, strengthening a culture in which research, knowledge transfer and dissemination go hand in hand with excellent, multidisciplinary and competitive science.
five key objectives to become a scientific benchmark committed to society
Organize iARCUS as an Institute with a culture of research, transfer, and dissemination.
Create multidisciplinary and competitive science of excellence.
Contribute knowledge to create new generations of scientists, supporting their professional development.
Contribute to solving the challenges of 21st-century society.
Involve society in scientific advances by promoting open science.

At the same time, it seeks to train new generations of scientists, face the great challenges of the 21st century through research and open up science to the public, actively involving them in its advances.
seeks to train new generations of scientists

In order to achieve the proposed objectives, strategic R&D&I priorities have been established focusing on the sustainable production of aquatic animals, the monitoring of the quality of the aquatic environment and its impact on health, food safety and traceability, the use of fish as biomedical models, and the development of analytical methodologies.
strategic R&D&I priorities
In a cross-cutting manner, education in resilience and knowledge of the environment is promoted as a fundamental axis for tackling environmental and health challenges.
education in resilience and knowledge of the environment

The institute has a team of more than 100 people, with an equal distribution in terms of gender. Of the total, more than 40 belong to the associated staff (approx. 50% women), together with postdoctoral researchers, trainees and technicians. They are organised into 11 specialised groups and 6 research teams.
more than 100 people
11 specialised groups and 6 research teams

Since its inauguration, it has registered a total of 26 patents and is currently involved in more than 30 projects. They have close collaboration with renowned international institutions, including CIIMAR (Portugal), CNRS (France) and DTU (Denmark), as well as strategic platforms such as the European Marine Board.
26 patents and is currently involved in more than 30 projects
iARCUS works around 3 strategic axes and one that acts transversally.
3 strategic axes

These axes are intended as a great opportunity to organise, adapt and coordinate with the different areas of knowledge and the current and future challenges in research, development and innovation in the aquatic world. These axes correspond to the three pillars that form the One Health triad.
organise, adapt and coordinate with the different areas of knowledge
WATER AND ANIMAL HEALTH (axis 1)

It focuses on sustainable aquaculture through the prevention and control of diseases in aquatic animals. It addresses pathology, water quality, traceability and food safety, promoting practices that ensure the health and sustainability of the sector.
Within this axis we find different research groups that are working on the parameters.
ACUIBIOMOL: Molecular and developmental biology in aquaculture
ACUIBIOMOL: Molecular and developmental biology in aquaculture
The genes that regulate the development, metamorphosis and reproductive cycle of bivalve molluscs are studied in order to improve their cultivation in marine environments.
DITAPREIN: Biotechnology for the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of infectious diseases
DITAPREIN: Biotechnology for the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of infectious diseases

Research focuses on creating vaccines, new treatments against microbes and studying bacteria that affect food. It also works with useful substances from the sea, cultivates microalgae in a controlled way and uses aquaculture waste to obtain beneficial products.
GIPA: Research Group in Aquaculture Pathology
GIPA: Research Group in Aquaculture Pathology

They investigate diseases caused by bacteria and viruses in aquaculture animals. They develop ways to detect and prevent these diseases, and study how they are transmitted and affect molluscs, using genetic and molecular tools.
NEURODEVO: Development and regeneration of the nervous system of fish
NEURODEVO: Development and regeneration of the nervous system of fish
They study how the nervous system of fish develops and organises itself, how it regenerates after injury, including the retina, and how biological rhythms influence the formation of new neurons.
PARAQUASIL: Interdisciplinary Group in Pharmaceutical Technology, Parasitic Immunobiology and Waterborne Parasitosis
PARAQUASIL: Interdisciplinary Group in Pharmaceutical Technology, Parasitic Immunobiology and Waterborne Parasitosis

Research is carried out on the transmission of protozoa through water and food, and treatments with cyclodextrins and controlled release systems are developed. We also study diseases and immunology in fish to develop effective vaccines.
SISMOL: Molecular Systematics
SISMOL: Molecular Systematics
Species identification by mitochondrial DNA techniques, alternative marine cultures, stress, immunity and its regulation and gene expression are studied.
WATER AND ENVIRONMENTAL (axis 2)
Addresses the effects of chemical pollution in the aquatic environment and its impact on animal and human health. It promotes the analysis and control of pollutants to protect ecosystems and health.
Around this axis we find several research groups whose research focuses on water and environmental health.
ChromChem: Chromatography and Chemometrics
ChromChem: Chromatography and Chemometrics
Advanced methods are being developed to detect contaminants, optimise the analysis of samples and apply artificial intelligence in analytical chemistry.
Analytical Chemistry-Lugo
Analytical Chemistry-Lugo

Advanced methods are studied to analyse agri-food products and wines from Galicia, focusing on the polyphenolic profile and its effect on health. Techniques are also being developed to detect metals, drugs and toxins in food and marine samples, improving environmental control and food quality.
WATER AND HUMAN HEALTH (axis 3)

Analyses how water pollution affects our health, the use of animals to understand diseases, the transmission of diseases between animals and humans (zoonoses), and the impact of certain natural or chemical substances on the human body.
A research group actively working in this area participates in this axis.
LREC: Escherichia coli reference laboratory
LREC: Escherichia coli reference laboratory

The laboratory specialises in the detection and molecular typing of different pathogenic strains of E. coli in food and clinical samples, including verotoxigenic and extraintestinal serotypes. They study pathogenesis, epidemiology and genetic resistance, developing advanced analytical methods and vaccines for colibacillosis.
EDUCATION IN RESILIENCE AND SUSTAINABILITY (transversal axis)
Promotes the formation of people and communities capable of adapting to environmental and social changes, promoting sustainable and responsible practices with the environment.
SEPA-Interdisciplinary: Social Pedagogy and Environmental Education
SEPA-Interdisciplinary: Social Pedagogy and Environmental Education

Environmental, social and community education is studied, as well as cultural policies in local government. In addition, the educational system in Galicia is analysed, as well as social perceptions on environmental education.

The iARCUS offers courses and training pills aimed at business professionals, freelancers and government technicians. Its mission is to transmit to society all the knowledge acquired throughout the research experience.
transmit to society all the knowledge acquired

The iARCUS Institute offers advanced scientific services to analyse substances and microorganisms in environmental, food or biological samples. For example, they detect more than 50 different pesticides in wine, grapes or agricultural soils, as well as drug and medicine residues in wastewater. They also identify bacteria such as Listeria or Salmonella in food, viruses such as VHSV or KHV in fish, and parasites in molluscs such as Bonamia ostreae.
offers advanced scientific services to analyse substances and microorganisms in environmental, food or biological samples
identify bacteria
In addition, they offer access to equipment such as digital PCR or ultracentrifuges for specialised research. All services can be tailored to the specific needs of the client.
access to equipment such as digital PCR or ultracentrifuges for specialised research

Patents focus on biotechnological solutions for aquaculture and animal health. They include methods to detect and control bacterial infections in fish, the development of specific vaccines, the use of marine probiotics and strategies to improve the quality of aquatic products.
Patents focus on biotechnological solutions
They also cover innovations in the analysis of canned species and the improvement of microalgae cultures.
Patents such as the quorum sensing inhibitor peptide are considered innovations with the potential to impact aquaculture internationally.
quorum sensing inhibitor peptide
TALENT AMBASSADORS
MANAGEMENT TEAM
Carlos Pereira Dopazo
José Benito Quintana Álvarez
RESEARCH STAFF
María Isabel Bandín Matos
Antón Barreiro Iglesias
José Manuel Leiro Vidal
Beatriz Magariños Ferro
Pablo Meira Cartea
Azucena Mora Gutiérrez
Ana María Otero Casal
Mª del Rosario Rodil Rodríguez
Isaac Rodríguez Pereiro
CARLOS PEREIRA DOPAZO
CARLOS PEREIRA DOPAZO
Director. Professor of Microbiology at the University
Director. Professor of Microbiology at the University
PhD in Microbiology from the USC. Author of more than a hundred scientific publications, he has been principal investigator in more than 20 research projects.

He was coordinator of the Galician Network of Biotechnology in Aquaculture (REGABA), coordinator of the International Network of Lower Vertebrate Viruses (INVLV), and in the official inter-university master\'s degree in Aquaculture in Galicia. He currently coordinates the state network EpiMar.
His lines of research focus on the epidemiology, prevention and control of viral diseases in aquaculture and in the natural aquatic environment.
Development of advanced diagnostic methods and evaluation of substances with potential antiviral activity.
Water and Animal Health and 3. Water and Human Health.
MORE INFO: https://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/59880/detalle?lang=es
JOSÉ BENITO QUINTANA ÁLVAREZ
JOSÉ BENITO QUINTANA ÁLVAREZ
Professor in the Area of Analytical Chemistry
Professor in the Area of Analytical Chemistry

He researches the development of analytical methods to detect organic pollutants and biomarkers, and studies their impact on environmental and human health. He also analyses wastewater to obtain epidemiological information through chemical biomarkers of substance abuse or human exposure to chemical pollutants.
Water and Environmental Health and 3. Water and Human Health.
MORE INFO: https://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/60011/detalle?lang=es
MARÍA ISABEL BANDÍN MATOS
MARÍA ISABEL BANDÍN MATOS
Senior Lecturer of Microbiology at the University
Senior Lecturer of Microbiology at the University

She focuses her research on the characterisation of virulence factors of pathogenic viruses in fish, with the aim of developing vaccines and preventive measures for aquaculture. It also evaluates bioactive substances with antiviral potential and studies their mechanisms of action. In addition, he conducts epidemiological studies in aquatic animals and in the natural environment to prevent new diseases.
Due to its experience, it is included in Axis 1. Water and Animal Health and Axis 3. Water and Human Health.
MORE INFO: https://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/58309/detalle?lang=es
ANTÓN BARREIRO IGLESIAS
ANTÓN BARREIRO IGLESIAS
Senior Lecturer of Cell Biology at the University
Senior Lecturer of Cell Biology at the University

He researches the use of fish as models in neurobiology and biomedicine, focusing on spinal cord injuries in the search for drugs that promote neuronal regeneration. He also studies the development of the nervous system and creates models of neurodegenerative diseases such as ataxias and diabetic retinopathy.
His research focuses on Axis 3: Water and Human Health.
MORE INFO: https://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/58336/detalle?lang=es
JOSÉ MANUEL LEIRO VIDAL
JOSÉ MANUEL LEIRO VIDAL
Professor in the Area of Parasitology
Professor in the Area of Parasitology

Dr. Leiro researches how the immune system of fish and molluscs responds to infections by protozoan parasites, studying the interaction between the parasite and the host, as well as the diagnosis and control of these diseases.
Water and Animal Health and 2. Water and Environmental Health of the Institute.
MORE INFO: https://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/59388/detalle?lang=es
BEATRIZ MAGARIÑOS FERRO
BEATRIZ MAGARIÑOS FERRO
Professor in the Area of Microbiology
Professor in the Area of Microbiology
Her lines of research focus on creating diagnostic methods to prevent bacterial diseases in freshwater and marine fish, and on developing vaccines to protect them from these diseases in aquaculture.
This research falls under Axis 1: Water and Animal Health.
MORE INFO: https://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/59539/detalle?lang=es
PABLO MEIRA CARTEA
PABLO MEIRA CARTEA
Senior Lecturer at the University in the Area of Theory and History of Education
Senior Lecturer at the University in the Area of Theory and History of Education

His research focuses on the study of the theoretical and methodological bases of Environmental Education and Communication, designing and evaluating policies and programmes on climate change and its socio-environmental problems.
It works on the design and experimentation of innovative educational resources to promote the transition towards more sustainable societies with the participation of different social groups.
It is part of the Transversal Axis. Education in resilience and sustainability.
MORE INFO: https://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/59631/detalle?lang=es
AZUCENA MORA GUTIÉRREZ
AZUCENA MORA GUTIÉRREZ
Professor in the Area of Microbiology
Professor in the Area of Microbiology
Dr. Mora leads the Food Safety and Antibiotic Resistance line from a "One Health" perspective.

She directs the Diagnostic and Advisory Service related to microbiological techniques to study pathogenic strains of E. coli and coordinates projects that seek to identify bio-indicators, including the aquatic environment, to monitor and control antibiotic resistance.
She is also a member of the Scientific Committee of the Spanish Agency for Food Safety and Nutrition.
Her experience is mainly focused on Axis 2: Water and environmental health and Axis 3: Water and human health.
MORE INFO: http://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/59695/detalle?lang=es
ANA MARÍA OTERO CASAL
ANA MARÍA OTERO CASAL
Professor of Microbiology at the University
Professor of Microbiology at the University

Her research focuses on two main complementary lines of research. On the one hand, she develops new strategies to combat bacterial pathogens that affect both animal and human health. On the other hand, he works in the field of biotechnology of photosynthetic microorganisms, improving the nutritional profile of microalgae for aquaculture, producing useful compounds and applying them in environmental treatments.
His group maintains multiple collaborations with other fields of environmental biotechnology (biodegradation of plastics), materials science, food safety and clinical microbiology.
They focus on Axis 1: Water and Animal Health and Axis 3: Water and Human Health.
MORE INFO: https://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/59797/detalle?lang=es
Mª DEL ROSARIO RODIL RODRÍGUEZ
Mª DEL ROSARIO RODIL RODRÍGUEZ
Professor in the Area of Analytical Chemistry
Professor in the Area of Analytical Chemistry

Her research is based on the development of analytical methods to detect organic pollutants and their metabolites in different environments (such as water and living organisms), and applies these methods to study their impact on environmental and human health.
Water and Environmental Health and 3. Water and Human Health.
MORE INFO: https://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/60114/detalle?lang=es
ISAAC RODRÍGUEZ PEREIRO
ISAAC RODRÍGUEZ PEREIRO
Professor in the Area of Analytical Chemistry
Professor in the Area of Analytical Chemistry

He develops analytical methods to detect organic pollutants in the environment and in plant foods. With these methods he studies their behaviour, persistence, transformation, elimination and risks to health and the environment. It also researches bioactive compounds in agricultural by-products.
Water and environmental health and 3. Water and human health.
MORE INFO: https://investigacion.usc.gal/investigadores/60197/detalle?lang=es
If you are interested in learning more about this institute, you can access more information by clicking on the following link:
learning more
